childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 2000-2012

Born in the year 2000 carried a symbolic weight their parents felt more than they ever would. Millennial babies, the new century's first class—hospitals handed out commemorative certificates, local papers ran human interest stories, and the general sentiment was that these children were arriving into a world of limitless possibility. That narrative lasted about eighteen months. By the time this cohort was forming first memories, the country had been attacked, the economy was contracting, and the optimism that greeted their birth had been replaced by something warier and more vigilant.

Their childhood unfolded in post-9/11 suburbia, a landscape that looked mostly the same as before but felt measurably different. Parents drove the same routes to the same schools, but the schools now had buzz-in entry systems and updated emergency plans. Flag decals appeared on car bumpers. Yellow ribbons on mailboxes signaled that someone on the street had a family member deployed. This cohort learned patriotism not as a history lesson but as a present-tense emotional condition—something adults performed with a new seriousness, particularly in the years when the wars were fresh and the collective grief was still raw.

The domestic rhythm of their early years had a distinctive split personality. Inside the house, childhood proceeded along familiar lines: board games on rainy Saturdays, arguments about bedtime, the slow accumulation of homework and chores that structures a kid's understanding of responsibility. Outside, the culture was reorganizing itself around fear and security in ways that seeped into everything. Travel required longer lead times. Public events acquired bag-check lines. The background assumption that America was fundamentally safe—an assumption so deep it had been invisible—was gone, replaced by a watchfulness that adults modeled and children absorbed without being told to.

At seven, the ground shifted again, though this cohort experienced it more as a change in household weather than a historical event. Smartphones arrived, and the adults in their lives started splitting attention in a new way—present but distracted, physically in the room but mentally elsewhere, thumbs moving across glass. Family dinners competed with notification chimes. Car rides got quieter as the driver's phone mounted on the dashboard became a third presence. This cohort caught the last years of childhood where boredom was a real condition rather than a choice, where a rainy afternoon meant staring at the ceiling or building something out of whatever was lying around, before the screens filled every gap.

At eight, the financial crisis restructured their family's emotional landscape. The recession manifested differently in every household—some lost jobs, some lost houses, some just lost the easy confidence that had characterized the years before. What nearly every child in this cohort experienced was a tonal shift: parents who'd been relaxed about spending became careful, conversations about money acquired a gravity that hadn't been there before, and the implicit promise of middle-class life—that hard work produced stability—developed a visible crack. They were old enough to notice and young enough that the noticing became foundational, a piece of their understanding of how the world worked that would never fully dislodge.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen Z Generation

Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. Those born in 2000 are positioned in the middle—not quite the eldest translators between digital worlds, not quite the true smartphone babies who never knew anything else. Gen Z is the generation too young to remember 9/11 consciously but old enough to be shaped entirely by its aftermath. Gen Z numbers roughly 68 million Americans.

Generational labels are imperfect, but the data is revealing: Gen Z is the most diverse generation in American history. They're also the most educated, though that education comes with the most debt. This generation grew up with school shootings as regular occurrences, lockdown drills as normal as fire drills. Columbine happened before they were born; Sandy Hook happened when they were twelve. Gen Z didn't adopt social media—they were raised by it, shaped by it, formed in its image.

Gen Z is often called 'digital natives,' which is accurate but incomplete. They're not just comfortable with technology—they're skeptical of it in ways early internet enthusiasts weren't. They watched Millennials get addicted to social media and learned from their posts. They understand that Instagram is fake, that algorithms manipulate them, that tech companies sell their data to anyone willing to pay. They use the tools anyway because there's no real alternative to participation. Gen Z has never expected stability because they've never experienced it.

Compared to Millennials, Gen Z is more pragmatic and less optimistic. Millennials believed the system could be fixed with enough hope and voting. Gen Z assumes it's broken and works around it. Millennials graduated into recession and hoped things would improve. Gen Z graduated into COVID and didn't bother hoping. This isn't nihilism—it's adaptation. Gen Z is building their own structures because the existing ones weren't made for them.

Gen Z is redefining everything from gender to work to success. They're less interested in climbing corporate ladders and more interested in not being miserable. They've watched older generations burn out and decided maybe that's not the goal. Mental health isn't shameful to them—it's just health. Therapy isn't weakness—it's maintenance.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 2000 brought Gladiator, which won Best Picture and Russell Crowe asked if audiences were entertained. *NSYNC's 'Bye Bye Bye' was everywhere—boy bands at peak market saturation. Britney Spears was at the height of Britney, and Christina Aguilera was getting 'Dirrty' in the videos parents probably didn't want children watching. The pop machine was running at full capacity.

Early childhood for this cohort was peak Disney Channel: That's So Raven, Kim Possible, Lizzie McGuire teaching that middle school was dramatic and consequential. By elementary school, they were watching Hannah Montana learn that fame comes at a cost—a lesson the internet would teach this entire generation in real time as influencer culture emerged. High School Musical convinced millions of kids that spontaneous choreography was normal. It wasn't, but the songs still hold up.

Middle school years for this cohort belonged to the iPhone era. Suddenly everyone had a camera, and everyone was documenting everything. This cohort got their first smartphone around age ten to twelve, give or take. Instagram launched when they were ten. Vine launched when they were twelve. They were the target demographic for content that lasted six seconds because attention spans were already fragmenting into smaller and smaller pieces.

Music in this cohort's formative years: Lady Gaga made weird mainstream. Taylor Swift transitioned from country to pop to whatever she wanted. Kanye West was still making music people could enjoy without moral calculus. By high school, streaming had killed the album. This cohort listened to playlists, not records. The idea of buying music physically seemed as quaint as rotary phones.

This generation's cultural references are different from every generation before because they all watched different things. There's no show everyone saw, no album everyone owned, no movie everyone watched in theaters together. Culture splintered into algorithmic niches. They bond over memes, not media. Their cultural touchstones are TikTok sounds and Twitter moments that last a week before being replaced by the next thing everyone forgets.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

This cohort was born into the dot-com bubble, which burst spectacularly a few months after they arrived. All those sock puppet mascots and 'eyeballs before profits' startups imploded. It was the first tech crash of their lifetime. It wouldn't be the last. The industry would recover, overcorrect, and crash in different ways. This generation has never known technology as a stable sector.

The iPhone launched when this cohort was seven—old enough to remember life before it, young enough to have their adolescence shaped entirely by its existence. They're not like Millennials, who got smartphones as adults, or the younger Gen Z kids who never knew anything else. They're the transition generation. They remember boredom. They remember not being reachable. They remember the freedom and terror of being truly alone with their thoughts.

Social media arrived in stages. Facebook was for old people by the time this cohort was old enough to want it. Instagram was their first real platform—filtered photos, curated lives, the beginning of performing existence for an audience. Snapchat added ephemerality; suddenly posts could disappear, which felt like freedom from permanence. TikTok arrived in their late teens and consumed everything. The algorithm knew them better than they knew themselves.

This cohort learned about coding—or at least became aware that coding existed—earlier than any previous generation. Their school probably had STEM initiatives, coding camps, robotics clubs. Whether they participated or not, technology wasn't mysterious. It was just infrastructure. They've never been impressed by someone knowing how to use a computer. That's like being impressed someone knows how to open a door.

Gen Z's relationship with technology is complicated in ways that older tech enthusiasts don't fully grasp. They know it's manipulating them. They know the attention economy extracts value from their eyeballs. They know that 'free' services are paid for with their data. But they use them anyway because the alternative—being disconnected—feels impossible. They've optimized for awareness without agency. They know the rules have shifted and they're playing it anyway.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

This cohort was one year old during 9/11. They have no memory of it, but they grew up in the world it created. The TSA, the Patriot Act, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq—this was normal to them. America at war was their childhood's background noise. The 'forever wars' started before they could walk and ended (sort of) when they were in their twenties.

Hurricane Katrina hit when this cohort was five. They probably don't remember it directly, but it was the first time this generation saw the government fail spectacularly in real-time on television. Bodies floating, people stranded on rooftops, a president who seemed disconnected from the drowning. It was a preview of coming attractions: the climate disasters that would define their adulthood.

At {{AGE_AT_IPHONE}}, the iPhone changed everything about how humans interact with information. The recession hit when this cohort was eight. They didn't understand credit default swaps or mortgage-backed securities, but they understood that adults were scared. Maybe their parents lost jobs, lost homes, lost confidence in institutions. The recovery was slow and uneven.

Obama's election happened when this cohort was eight. A Black president was normal to them in a way it wasn't for older generations who remembered different possibilities. Then Trump happened when they were sixteen, and suddenly the adults who'd told them racism was mostly over couldn't explain what was happening. This cohort watched the country reveal itself, and it wasn't pretty.

School shootings punctuated this cohort's education. Sandy Hook happened when they were twelve. Parkland happened when they were eighteen—and this time, the kids fought back. March For Our Lives was this generation's first major political mobilization. They learned that outrage doesn't guarantee change, but they also learned that silence guarantees defeat.

At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, COVID-19 hit. If this cohort was in college, they got sent home mid-semester. If they were entering the workforce, the workforce disappeared. Graduation ceremonies happened via Zoom if they happened at all. The pandemic compressed years of change into months: remote work, remote school, remote everything. This cohort lost time they won't get back.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

This cohort entered the workforce around 2022, which means they graduated into whatever that was. The pandemic hangover. The Great Resignation. The economy where unemployment was low but so were real wages, and everyone was hiring but nobody was paying enough to live on. Welcome to their career: it started confusing and shows no signs of clarifying.

Remote work is normal to Gen Z in ways it isn't for older workers. They don't romanticize the office. They've seen how much time commuting wastes, how many meetings could have been emails, how much 'collaboration' is actually surveillance in a fancier package. They want flexibility because they've seen that the work gets done either way, and sitting in a cubicle doesn't make anyone more productive.

Gen Z is skeptical of hustle culture. They watched Millennials burn out chasing the dream, posting inspirational quotes about grinding while their mental health collapsed and their promotions never materialized. They're not interested in being a girlboss or a founder bro. They want reasonable hours, decent pay, and a life outside of work.

Side hustles are normal to Gen Z, but not because they find them empowering. They do them because one job often isn't enough. They've seen the gig economy's promise ('be one's own boss!') and its reality ('no benefits, no stability, algorithmic tyranny'). They understand that flexibility often means exploitation with better marketing.

Gen Z is entering a job market where AI can do significant portions of entry-level work. The jobs of their childhood don't exist anymore. The jobs they'll have at forty don't exist yet. AI is coming for white-collar work the way automation came for manufacturing. This generation will have to adapt constantly—reskilling, pivoting, staying relevant in a labor market being disrupted faster than anyone can track.

What Gen Z wants from work is different from what previous generations wanted. Boomers wanted stability. Gen X wanted independence. Millennials wanted meaning. Gen Z wants honesty. Just tell them what the job actually is, pay fairly for the work, and don't pretend it's a family. They'll do the work. Don't insult their intelligence with pizza parties while they're doing it.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Gen Z has never known dating without apps. Sure, they could theoretically meet someone 'in the wild,' but the infrastructure of modern courtship is digital. Swipe right, match, text for days before meeting, repeat. They've normalized the paradox of infinite choice leading to decision paralysis. When everyone is available, no one feels special. When everyone could be better, settling feels like failure.

Gen Z communicates differently than any generation before. They text, obviously, but texting feels formal compared to DMs, Snaps, and TikTok comments. They have different communication channels for different intimacy levels. A phone call is either very serious or very weird. FaceTime is for close friends and family. They've developed an entire semiotics around response times, emoji usage, and read receipts.

Gen Z is surprisingly traditional in some ways. Studies show Gen Z actually wants long-term relationships, marriage, kids—the conventional milestones. They're just practical about the obstacles. Marriage costs money. Kids cost more. Housing is impossible. They want the life their grandparents had; they just can't afford it.

Friendship in Gen Z is maintained digitally across distance in ways that weren't possible before. Their best friend might live in another state. They've bonded with people they've never met in person through Discord servers, Twitter threads, or gaming communities. Online relationships are real relationships. The people who dismiss internet friends as fake don't understand that Gen Z has grown up with the internet as a social space, not just a tool.

Gen Z is more open about mental health in relationships than previous generations. They talk about boundaries, attachment styles, therapy. They've normalized saying 'I need space' or 'that triggered me.' Some older people find this excessive. Gen Z finds it honest. They'd rather address problems than pretend they don't exist until they destroy everything.

Gen Z is redefining what relationships look like. Traditional timelines—date, engaged, married, kids—feel less mandatory. Some of them want that path. Some want something different. The expectation that everyone follows the same script has loosened, which is liberating for those outside the norm and overwhelming for those who liked having a script to follow.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

This cohort was {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}} during the 2008 crash. They don't remember the technical details of subprime mortgages and credit default swaps, but they remember the vibes: stressed parents, foreclosure signs in neighborhoods, the sense that money was scary and unpredictable. Gen Z has never believed in economic stability because they've never seen it last.

College, if this cohort went, came with debt. Average student loan debt for this cohort is around $30,000, though plenty have more. They were told education was the path to success, then handed a bill that will follow them for decades. The math doesn't work, but the alternatives—no degree, fewer opportunities—seem worse. They're paying for a credential that depreciated before they finished earning it.

Housing feels impossible. Home prices have outpaced wages for this cohort's entire adult life. The median home costs more than ever relative to median income. Their parents might have bought a house in their twenties. This cohort is watching from their rental, doing the math, realizing it doesn't add up no matter how they run the numbers. The homeownership dream isn't dead for Gen Z—it was never alive.

Gen Z saves, but not for retirement in the traditional sense. They save for emergencies because they've seen how fast things fall apart. They keep a buffer because the safety net has holes big enough to fall through. Traditional financial advice—invest early, compound interest, retire at 65—assumes stability they've never experienced. They're planning for uncertainty because certainty isn't available.

Gen Z is surprisingly financially literate, partly because they had to be and partly because TikTok made financial concepts accessible content. They learned about investing from Reddit threads and YouTube videos. They understand meme stocks are gambling but gambled anyway because what's the alternative, a savings account that loses to inflation? The traditional financial system doesn't work for them, so they've explored parallel systems—some smart, some reckless, all interesting.

Gen Z's financial goals are different from their parents'. Their parents wanted accumulation: house, cars, retirement account, visible wealth. Gen Z wants freedom: enough money to not be trapped, enough flexibility to walk away from bad situations. They're not irresponsible. They're rational actors responding to irrational conditions.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Gen Z's biggest blind spot is assuming everyone has the same access to information they do. They grew up with the internet, so they assume competence is just a YouTube tutorial away. But not everyone learns that way. Not everyone has the same digital literacy. Gen Z can be accidentally condescending to people who struggle with things they find intuitive.

Gen Z is so attuned to systemic problems that they sometimes miss individual agency. Everything is structural to them—capitalism, patriarchy, white supremacy, ableism, the algorithm. These systems are real and worth critiquing. But sometimes the problem is also that one specific person made a bad choice. Both can be true. Their analytical framework can become a way of avoiding personal responsibility.

Gen Z is chronically online in ways that distort their perception of reality. The discourse on Twitter is not the country. TikTok trends are not culture. The takes they see are curated by algorithms to maximize engagement, which means outrage and conflict get amplified. They know this intellectually, but it's hard to feel it when they're scrolling. Their worldview is shaped by what gets amplified, and what gets amplified isn't what's typical.

Gen Z is conflict-averse in person while being conflict-fluent online. They can argue fiercely in comments but freeze in face-to-face confrontation. This is a problem because power isn't negotiated in comment sections. The people who control things—boards, legislatures, boardrooms—meet in person. Digital activism matters, but it's not sufficient. At some point they have to show up physically, and that's harder for a generation raised on screens.

Gen Z sometimes mistakes information for action. They're well-informed about problems—climate change, inequality, injustice—but information doesn't equal impact. Knowing about a problem doesn't solve it. Sharing an infographic doesn't change policy. Gen Z has the awareness; what's less clear is whether they have the follow-through to translate awareness into sustained, boring, institutional change.

Gen Z has inherited irony as a defense mechanism, which makes earnestness feel dangerous. Caring too much about something is cringe. Admitting they want things—success, love, meaning—feels vulnerable. So they couch everything in jokes and layers of distance. This protects them from disappointment, but it also prevents connection. At some point, they have to drop the irony and mean what they say.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2020-2030): This cohort is in this decade now, and it's challenging. They graduated into a pandemic, entered a job market that couldn't decide if it was booming or collapsing, and they're trying to build a life while everything feels unstable. Traditional milestones—career progression, relationships, housing—are happening on delayed timelines if they're happening at all. This is supposed to be their foundation-building decade, but the ground keeps shifting. The best they can do is stay adaptable, build skills that transfer, and try not to compare themselves to timelines that no longer apply.

The 30s (2030-2040): By their thirties, the chaos of their twenties should consolidate into something more stable. Emphasis on 'should.' They'll probably have a clearer career direction, even if it's not what they expected. Relationships—romantic, platonic, familial—will matter more as they realize life is long and lonely without them. If they want kids, this is statistically when most people have them. If they don't want kids, this is when they'll get tired of explaining that choice. This decade is about choosing what they're building toward, knowing they can't have everything.

The 40s (2040-2050): Peak earning years, peak responsibility. They'll probably be managing people at work, whether they want to or not. If they have kids, they'll be the age they were during their formative memories—weird to contemplate. Their parents will be aging, and they'll start dealing with their mortality in concrete ways. This is the sandwich decade: caring for generations above and below them while trying to maintain their own identity. The key skill is saying no—to obligations, to guilt, to the endless demands on their time. They can't do everything. Choosing what to prioritize is the work.

The 50s (2050-2060): The world in their fifties will be different enough that predictions are unreliable. Climate change will have reshaped geography, economics, and migration patterns. AI will have transformed work in ways we can barely anticipate from here. But some things will be constant: they'll be thinking about legacy, about what they've built and what they're leaving behind. They'll have perspective their younger self lacked—both the wisdom that comes from experience and the regrets that come from choices they can't unmake.

The 60s and beyond (2060+): Retirement for Gen Z will look nothing like their grandparents' retirement—golf and Social Security and twenty stable years. It might not be retirement at all in the traditional sense. The economics don't support it, and the concept itself is rooted in industrial-age assumptions about work and age. What they'll have instead is transition: shifting from primary earner to something else, finding meaning outside of productivity, contending with a body that has opinions about their activities. They've never expected stability. That continues.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

This cohort is part of roughly {{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people born in {{BIRTH_YEAR}}. Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), Gen Z is more pragmatic and less optimistic about what institutions can deliver. Millennials believed the system could be reformed with enough effort and voting. Gen Z assumes it's broken and builds around it. Millennials were surprised by the 2008 crash. Gen Z was shaped by it as children. Millennials are angry about what was taken from them. Gen Z can't miss what they never had.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), Gen Z has almost nothing in common except a shared irony and distrust of institutions. Gen X were latchkey kids who became slackers who became middle managers. Gen Z are digital natives who became content creators who will become... whatever comes next. Gen X had the privilege of being ignored; Gen Z has the burden of being watched, always, by algorithms and peers alike.

Gen X controlled 21% of national wealth at this age; Gen Z controls roughly 5%. Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is significant. Boomers bought houses on single incomes when houses cost what cars cost now. They had pensions, union jobs, affordable education, and they voted to dismantle all of that before Gen Z could vote to keep it. The intergenerational transfer of wealth is not going in Gen Z's direction.

Life expectancy for Gen Z is uncertain. Previous generations could assume roughly eighty years. Gen Z might get more—medical advances—or might get less—climate change, inequality, mental health challenges. Gen Z is the most connected generation in history and also the loneliest. They've grown up with the knowledge that the future is not guaranteed, which is psychologically different from previous generations who assumed progress was inevitable.

But here's the thing: every generation thinks it's special, and every generation is wrong. Gen Z will make the same mistakes as those who came before, just in new forms. They'll eventually become the older generation that younger people blame for their problems. Whether that's enough to offset the structural disadvantages they've inherited remains to be seen.

year_events: Y2K turned out to be an expensive non-event
Bush v. Gore went to the Supreme Court
The first season of Survivor aired
